Charmine's story demonstrates the best of our migration system, a system we are determined to restore so that the next chapter of the Australian multicultural story continues to be one of success.

Mr WOOD (La Trobe) (17:17): My questions are directed to the Minister for Immigration, Citizenship and Multicultural Affairs who has joined us here today in the Federation Chamber, and I think it would be unfair for another Labor member to answer these questions because they very much relate to issues raised by the Afghan community directly with me. Why is the government scrapping a crucial visa program, the locally engaged employee visa program, otherwise known as the LEE program, for Afghans who worked for Australia, including interpreters who supported Australian soldiers? Why is Labor betraying Afghan interpreters who put their lives and even their families at risk to support Australian soldiers during the Afghan deployment? Why has the government abandoned processing refugee applications for potentially thousands of people trapped in Afghanistan? Do they now need to flee Afghanistan and enter the neighbouring countries of Iran and Pakistan, for example, to have their visas processed? Does this mean that the thousands of Afghans currently trapped in Afghanistan must either face remaining there under the Taliban rule or undertake a dangerous trip across the border?

Just for background, the previous coalition government created this crucial LEE visa program to protect Afghans who supported our troops. After Labor promised the world to Afghan communities during the election campaign, this is how they are treated. The previous coalition government evacuated around 4,600 Afghan refugees in a few days and committed to a strong humanitarian intake of Afghan nationals with around 31,500 visas processed, and I understand this will also be hopefully honoured by the new government. Many Afghan families are still waiting to be reunited with loved ones, and Labor is crushing their hopes until they get some answers. The Department of Home Affairs has stated that anyone in Afghanistan it does not consider a priority—to be honest, everyone over there should be a priority—will have their applications refused. It says it cannot carry out background checks since the Islamic group reclaimed the country in August 2021. This leaves thousands of Afghans trapped in Afghanistan who now must either remain or flee.

My second minor question for the immigration minister is around the Local Multicultural Projects grant opportunity opened on 7 February 2023. Will the minister please explain the reason for the closed non-competitive process of this grant, considering there are many multicultural communities across Australia, other than those who were invited to apply, who are also deserving candidates for this grant? Will the minister please explain what consultation process was undertaken by the Department of Home Affairs to determine the eligibility criteria for applicants for the grant? How is it fair to the wider multicultural community to fund only those organisations who were invited to apply for the grant?

For some background on this, on 7 February 2023 the Department of Home Affairs opened Local Multicultural Projects grant opportunities via the community grants hub, and closed it on 20 February. There were only 13 days to apply. The total funding was just over $5 million over three years. The purposes and objectives of the program were to support organisations with grants, to develop new multicultural infrastructure, including places of worship, to upgrade existing multicultural committee facilities, and to celebrate key multicultural events and festivals, which we all agree are very worthy. But the eligibility of applicants was determined by their ability to identify and deliver to their local communities events, services and amenities which met program objectives. However, no further organisations will be invited to apply, so it was very much an open-and-shut case. The grant opportunities closed the non-competitive grant selection process. The department considers that is an appropriate type of selection process. Does the minister agree that is a fair way to conduct a grants process considering the previous Labor opposition was so scathing of programs under the Liberal government supporting, in particular, migrant communities and places of worship when they had been attacked? I respectfully request that the minister respond to these questions at the appropriate time.

Mr KHALIL (Wills) (17:22): Cybersecurity incidents are on the rise and are a threat to Australia's national interest and safety. Cybercrime is thought to be the biggest threat facing any business with an online presence. It has cost Australia around $42 billion in the last financial year, according to the Australian Cyber Security Centre and the University of New South Wales. Many people feel you can't put a price tag on our private data—that is certainly true—our electricity grid or our online economy. They are so valuable. The wider community feels this investment and Home Affairs' work in this space is worth continuing. It's important to strengthen our protections across all of this space.

Over the 2021-22 financial year, more than 76,000 cybercrime reports were made via ReportCyber, with one cybercrime report made approximately every seven minutes. There are many factors that feed into the global cyber threat we are experiencing. Russia's invasion of Ukraine has increased this threat globally. We have seen many malicious actors—both state and nonstate actors—seeking to garner and capture the sensitive and private information of citizens. They do this by targeting Australians and their small businesses. Most incidents identified by the Australian Cyber Security Centre noted the use of very simple techniques, and a lot of this can be protected with very simple defences. People in my electorate of Wills have contacted me about the issues that they face. One woman was quite distressed about being called by scammers as well as contacted online, and she immediately reported this and came to me.

She immediately reported this and came to me. There are others who have been very worried about the security of their small businesses and their websites. They're worried about being prey to these malicious attacks. Of course, many contacted my office after being victims of the cyber incident involving Optus.

People are rightly worried about their data and their private information being in the wrong hands. As a government, we are very aware of this real threat to cybersecurity. We are aware that cybersecurity issues are prevalent and exceeding anything that we've seen before. Unfortunately, the previous government failed to deliver any leadership on cybersecurity. They abolished the role of cybersecurity in the ministry. They failed to mandate cyber incident reporting obligations to government. They failed to deliver on the need for stronger penalties to protect online privacy. They failed to report publicly on the effectiveness of the 2020 cybersecurity strategy. How can we improve systems if we don't even know whether our systems are working? As a nation, we were left woefully underprepared by those opposite when they were in government. Because of their failures, we were not able to be resilient when it came to the impacts of cyberattacks. We had poor data and security in this space.

On this side, the Albanese government is a responsible government. We are a government that supports the Australian people. If you fall the into a cyberattack or a data breach, we will support you no matter where you are in Australia. We've committed to making Australia the most cybersecure nation in the world by 2030. The other mob are all talk, no action. This government has already started doing the work, albeit quietly and effectively—but that's important. We've already set up the 'hack the hackers' task force. This is a 100-strong task force of ASD and AFP officers who are hacking back at criminals seeking harm Australia and Australians. We are delivering $19.5 million to protect our most critical infrastructure assets through the Cyber and Infrastructure Security Centre. We're working closely with industry to develop Australia's new national cybersecurity strategy and we're building a national office for cybersecurity within the Department of Home Affairs. We're working across multiple portfolios in delivering this new national cybersecurity exercise program.

At a community level we are supporting individuals, businesses and organisations in being able to report a cybercrime incident or vulnerability through the Australian Cyber Security Centre. There is more work to be done, but that is already underway. We want to build a capacity to ensure people are more prepared and work together towards this government's commitment to making Australia the most cybersecure nation in the world by 2030. I want to assure the Australian people to feel more at ease that this government, these ministers—the home affairs minister, the minister for immigration—are working day in, day out to secure Australians' personal information and keep them secure from cybersecurity incidents, which are a serious threat to our safety and our national interest. This government is taking action and doing the job.

Mr CONAGHAN (Cowper) (17:27): In a free and modern society such as Australia, the word 'slavery' is not one that generally comes up at the dinner table. As Australians, we believe that in this country workers are protected, that they have the opportunity to earn a basic wage and that no-one can be forced into a job that they don't want to do and doesn't meet our country's strict standards. For the most part, that's true. We have systems in place set by all levels of government and avenues that our citizens and visa holders can take to call out employers who do not meet those standards. Unfortunately, there is an uncomfortable reality that, in the peripheries of our day-to-day lives right here in Australia, modern slavery and exploitation are more prevalent than we would like to imagine.

These issues are particularly concerning amongst immigrant populations and affect more women than they do men. Where there are vulnerable people, there will be predators and predatory practices from those set to benefit from their exploitation, and it is our bipartisan role to provide adequate protections against slavery and, conversely, adequate penalties for those who abuse their positions of power. I would like to acknowledge the work of my colleagues, the former minister and assistant minister for home affairs, who successfully implemented the Modern Slavery Act 2018, further progressing the policy with the National Action Plan to Combat Modern Slavery 2020-25 and then adding to this with the creation of the Support for Trafficked People Program. These were not small advancements in this space, and each who contributed to these policies and programs from all sides of the floor should be thanked and congratulated for their bipartisan efforts. But I do need to give particular kudos to the current Leader of the Opposition, the member for McPherson and the member for Mitchell for spearheading these initiatives during their time in their ministerial roles with the Department of Home Affairs.

This new government, in its second budget, has committed additional funding to this space—sadly, this has been driven by an increase in demand, and I don't sheet that home to the current government—continuing the work started by my coalition colleagues, and I thank them for their renewed commitment to these critical programs. I'd like to acknowledge the $23.4 million that will be provided over four years. It has been earmarked to increase the support provided in the original Support for Trafficked People Program from 45 days to 90 days. This was available as an extension in certain circumstances, but has been made standard through these measures. As well, there will be an 18-month pilot program to allow direct referrals from community providers without the need to engage with the AFP. It is completely understandable, when you see police agencies from overseas who are particularly corrupt, that some victims, particularly immigrants, are afraid to make a report to the AFP in case it affects their visa status or perhaps have a distrust of police in general. Having been police officer and a prosecutor, I've seen that firsthand, so it's good to have a trusted, internationally recognised brand like the Australian Red Cross involved. It's very pleasing to see that, and I'm keen to see the outcome of this pilot.

Having said that, when dealing with third-party organisations, and even with our own internal entities, there needs to be appropriate checks and balances in place, so my question to the minister is: what are the checks and balances that will be implemented to protect the integrity of the proposed 18-month STPP referrals pilot program, and can the minister ensure that a review of the program and the results and findings will be reported to parliament? My second question is: can the minister outline the role of the New South Wales Anti-slavery Commissioner, particularly with reference to the sexual servitude space in the National Plan to End Violence against Women and Children? Finally I would like to ask the minister to provide a concrete commitment to the Australian Centre to Counter Child Exploitation to ensure that the important work that they are doing is adequately funded and resourced.

Mr LAXALE (Bennelong) (17:32): I'm proud to represent one of the most diverse communities in Australia. I acknowledge the member for Fowler, who probably represents a community that's a little bit more diverse than mine. But, I can tell you what, I'm very proud to represent a very diverse community in Bennelong. Sixty-six per cent of those who live in Bennelong have one or both parents born overseas. Over 50 per cent of my community speak a language other than English at home. That diversity makes our community stronger, and migration and immigration into this country makes our community stronger. Each and every month, I have the pleasure of going to a citizenship ceremony at one of the three local councils in my area. It's something I've been doing for nearly a decade now in my role as a councillor and mayor, and it's one of my favourite things to do is an elected official. I share that special day with locals who have been in the community for a little while, having come from overseas and having made that really hard decision to leave their homeland and move to Australia, just like my parents did back in the sixties and eighties. They make that really hard decision to uproot their families and move to Australia because it's a land of promise and hope. To celebrate that day with them is something that I really relish.

I'm so glad that this government has fixed up the mess that was left behind by the former government in immigration processing and visa times. Citizenship is exactly an area in which this government has made many, many inroads. In the last 12 months alone the backlog of citizenship applications has been reduced by 30 per cent, with the number of applications now sitting at below 93,000 the first time in six years. That is quite an achievement. In the past 12 months alone, over 173,000 people have received Australian citizenship through conferral. That's an 18 per cent increase on the year before. Average processing times have also undergone a substantial reduction of 40 per cent, with more than 90 per cent of applicants only waiting six months to attend a ceremony.

I have witnessed this feedback firsthand. I remember not that long ago, particularly when we had to do citizenship ceremonies during the pandemic, we had to do some of these processes online. I remember asking people: 'How long has the process been? Has it been difficult?' They would say: 'We've been waiting two, three years for our citizenship. It's been a difficult process.' I had feedback at the citizenship ceremony in Ryde only a few weeks ago that someone had their application processed and became an Australian citizen within six months. That is something that is a direct consequence of a Labor government, because we value immigration, we value citizenship and we value a pathway to permanent residency and citizenship, which those opposite just did not.

When we came to government, over one million visas were left unprocessed. We had a previous government that told people to go home, to leave this country, rather than helping them to stay here. They said, 'Leave,' and they had no plan for reopening the borders. We had to employ 684 new staff to support the visa system to get through this backlog, because we on this side of the House understand the importance of migration to our social fabric and the importance of migration to our economy. The Liberal legacy was dire. They undermined Australia's visa system. They prioritised temporary immigration over permanent residency and citizenship, and they told people to go home during the pandemic and had no plan for when the border opened.

In the last few months, we've seen these attacks on immigrants and on migrants go even further. We've had questions in question time and MPIs blaming new citizens and migrants and those who choose to make Australia home for the failures of the past 10 years of their government. They're blaming migration for traffic jams in Sydney. They're blaming migration for the housing crisis that they left us with. Shame on them for doing that. We on this side of the House will never do that, because we know that a secure, transparent and efficient migration system makes this country strong. It is what our country was built on. It's what our economy was built on. I am very proud to be here as a son of parents who made that decision to move from overseas and come to Australia. They were welcomed with open arms, and never should that change. Never should migrants be blamed for 10 years of inaction on infrastructure delivery from the former government. We are tackling some of these issues that they raise, but we will not be blaming migration for them. I ask the minister to update the House on what improvements have been made to the visa processing system since forming government.

Ms LE (Fowler) (17:37): I thank the member for Bennelong. I agree that our electorates are some of the most diverse in the country. I think mine is the most diverse; I have to claim that. Last week, we welcomed 500 new Australian citizens in a Fairfield City Council citizenship ceremony, so I share your view on the importance of this Appropriation Bill (No. 1) 2023-2024. The government recently presented to us, the crossbench, and showed us the summary of what the migration review has revealed about our visa system. It is convoluted and complex and has a network of categories and visas that really looks like a web. I think it leaves the spiderweb for dead.

While I applaud the Minister for Home Affairs for taking on the challenge to review our migration process, I also encourage her to include in this review a look at what happens after migrants or refugees have settled. As I have previously said, my community has firsthand experience of the impact of migration and refugee settlement. We are a multicultural melting pot, with our country built on the shoulders of migrants and refugees, dating back as far as post World War II, with the influx of German and Italian migrants. Recently, we settled 12,000 Syrian refugees in Fairfield City Council alone—more than the rest of the state of New South Wales. However, we have not received the funding for basic infrastructure and services to match the settlement responsibilities our city took on. Our roads, public transport and hospitals aren't funded to support the increased population pressure and needs. Our schools are bursting at the seams with limited resources—human and capital. Now the cost-of-living and housing crises are acutely felt by everyone. I asked the minister: Will the review also take into consideration housing and infrastructure needs to support newly arrived migrants as well as current residents?

I acknowledge that, as part of the budget, the government will introduce an improved delivery model for the Adult Migrant English Program from 1 January 2025 to allow migrants and citizens to improve their ability to speak the English language, which I have benefitted from as a former refugee myself, so I know the importance of learning the English language. As well, it will help gain employment and other settlement outcomes. I welcome the improved delivery model; however, there is no additional funding allocated in this budget, so how will the model be improved with no additional funding? How will it get rolled out across the 300 locations in Australia? And which electorates will be prioritised? When settling into a new country, migrants need as much support as possible for them to feel secure and part of the community. It is imperative the government address these needs within the review.

The budget revealed that $75.8 million is to be allocated for improving visa processing over the course of two years. In the past decade, Australia has undeniably experienced an influx of visa applications with skilled and humanitarian migrants. I am sure I speak for many electorate officers when I say our staff and our officers feel the impact of the inefficiency and clogs within the current visa processing system. We are inundated with inquiries from our constituents about the delay in processing time, as the Department of Home Affairs is unable to keep up with the number of applications coming through. There is a human cost, as the delay to the application process causes anxiety for people having to wait for an outcome. I had a constituent who applied for a temporary protection visa and who has been caught up in the process and delayed for approximately four years. Migration is by far one of the most significant issues in my electorate of Fowler. Just in the last year, nearly 30 per cent of our cases are to do with immigration, visas or passports, the biggest portion of constituent work by a long shot.

Over the weekend I had the pleasure to join the Sabian Mandaean community for their remembrance day. Many were lucky to be settled in Australia after surviving trauma and atrocities of war in their homeland, but they have spent years waiting for answers as to why some of the family, friends and community members are still living in limbo in Turkiye. I ask the minister: What are the measures being implemented by the Department of Home Affairs to improve the efficiency of visa processing times? Can the minister clarify which visa application streams will benefit from this additional funding? For example, will humanitarian visa applications be prioritised over skilled migrant visas? As is clear when it comes to migration, many factors come into play. We need to ensure those who come to this lucky country have every chance to succeed in their new lives, whether they come as international students, skilled professionals or part of a humanitarian intake.

Mr GILES (Scullin—Minister for Immigration, Citizenship and Multicultural Affairs) (17:43): I'm pleased to have the opportunity to respond to many of the issues raised by colleagues in this debate. I will start with the member for Fowler. I did touch on the improved processing times that we have achieved. Due to the hard work of staff and additional investments, they are significantly lower, and we have reduced the backlog enormously, if you look to particular visa categories.

Perhaps I will make the offer here in the Federation Chamber: obviously the member for Fowler knows how to find me. I would be very pleased to go through those issues and our vision for the AMEP with her. She would be aware in the previous budget there was an additional investment made to identify some of the efficiencies and some of the ways in which you can reach more people to ensure everyone gets the English language skills they need to be an effective citizen and to fulfil their potential in our country. I welcome her contribution, as always, and look forward to further discussions.

The member for Cowper made a great contribution which went beyond my portfolio responsibilities but I will convey his remarks to the Attorney-General and reiterate that everyone in this parliament stands against modern slavery and stands resolved to ensure that our legislative framework and our enforcement regime are fit for purpose. The same goes for migrant worker exploitation, which is within my direct responsibility. I was pleased to hear his reflections based on his experience in a former life. I said to him that we have heard from people like him who have said we do need a firewall so that people who have been exploited in the workplace can come forward without fear of their visa being cancelled. We have acted on advice that he has given me in this chamber now and advice others have been given, and I'd be very pleased to go through the details of that with him.

The member for La Trobe raised a number of issues as did the shadow minister for immigration, Mr Tehan, and I will respond to some of them; time doesn't permit me to respond to all of them. Can I ask both shadow ministers to reflect from time to time on some of the language which they use because on some of these issues we really need to think about how what we say impacts people's lives and their decisions. In respect of Afghanistan, I think this is particularly challenging. I acknowledge the member for Mitchell and the work he did at the time of the evacuation, which was an extraordinary time. I am proud as an Australian of the efforts of the Australian government and all of our forces, in Home Affairs, in the military and in other departments, to get people to safety. I acknowledge that here we disagree on many things, but I admire the work that he did. The challenge since then has been great for both governments, and we acknowledge that we have an enormous demand from people who are particularly vulnerable because of the work they have done for and with Australians.

We have around 160,000 applications before us from Afghans. We are determined to do what you did in government—you, the current opposition—and give effect to the priorities that were determined by the former government in consultation with the Australian Afghan community. Shadow minister Wood, I think you should reflect on the language that you used about the priorities. I think you should reflect on your language, and the reference you made to the current Australian government is unworthy of any member of this parliament.
Mr Wood interjecting—

Mr GILES: I will answer that question by saying that we have committed to implementing in full the Thom report. You should read it, and you should speak about it accurately. You should read it, and you should reflect accurately. You should stop misleading people, and you should tell the truth. That should not be too much to ask. These are very difficult issues that we are grappling with in government, as you grappled with these issues as a government.
Mr Wood interjecting—
Mr GILES: You well know the answer to that question.

The member for Wannon also raised a large number of issues, and I will respond to a couple of them very quickly. Again, I ask him to reflect on the language he uses, the inflammatory and frankly wrong language that he uses, the divisive language that he uses about immigration and its impacts, particularly given the comments he made like, 'Well, we need to get our international students back, we need to get working holiday visa holders back and get all those people back as soon as we can.' He said that, but he seems to have forgotten about it, when these of course are the people who are returning after the pause in the pandemic and who are impacting temporarily the NOM. He should reflect on that. He raised an important individual case, and I will say this: as he well knows, I can't comment on the individual case in this place, and he should reflect on that. Secondly, he should know that I take very seriously every representation made by members of parliament, and I consider them on their merits in accordance with the law.
Proposed expenditure agreed to.
Consideration in Detail
Proposed expenditure, $38,035,132,000

Mr SHORTEN (Maribyrnong—Minister for the National Disability Insurance Scheme and Minister for Government Services) (17:49): Good evening, everybody. I am pleased to speak in this debate on the Appropriation Bill (No. 1) 2023-2024. I will cover a few topics with regard to my dual portfolio responsibility of government services and the NDIS. I will speak of the tangible benefits both agencies offer Australians and how the Albanese government's budget not only secures and improves their opportunities in the future but provides a vision for how we can better support Australians. I might start with the Services Australia emergency response. I'm pleased to announce that the budget allocation will boost the agency's vital work in emergency response and in sustaining myGov. Services Australia has a workforce about 30,000 strong, about 20 per cent of the Public Service. It administers $226 billion in payments each year. It has 318 service centres, 364 agent services and 212 access points. Australians are more likely than not to interact with Services Australia in their lifetime, across areas as broad as health, child care, education and retirement, and Services Australia supports Australians in their hour of greatest need, when they are impacted by natural disasters.

I saw the work of Services Australia staff up close in the first months in my portfolio, including in my own community, along the Maribyrnong River, which was inundated by floodwaters last October. I'm proud to say that, as the minister responsible for Services Australia, I saw responsive, professional, compassionate staff, easily identifiable in their blue polo shirts. They lived up to their 'interaction over transaction', 'person first, process second' approach. I think Australians doing it tough across the country gain a sense of comfort when they are able to access their services from Services Australia in a timely manner. They are connected to government services. They can get emergency payments in their bank accounts even before they leave the makeshift service centres. It's also great that we have four mobile service centres. Over 17 years they've visited 185,000 people in 6,100 communities, with more than a million kilometres of travel. In fact, just this morning, along with Minister Murray Watt, I launched our latest service centre on wheels, Kangaroo Paw II. It's now winding its way to its home base on the west coast, where it will be prepositioned to help the regional and remote communities of Western Australia.

I think the experience of the last three years of natural disasters has demonstrated that it's smarter and more economical to create these mobile workforces rather than assemble an expensive ad hoc workforce immediately after the disaster. So we've allocated $231.8 million in the budget to deliver better outcomes, to have 850 extra staff available to do disaster relief work, because natural disasters seem to be the rule, not the exception, these days. We've also been investing significantly in myGov. We've invested $134 million to continue myGov's operation. I'm pleased to say that today we announced that two million Australians have uploaded the myGov app.
Turning briefly to the NDIS, our object here is to get the NDIS back on track. It is fair to say that, after nine years of the coalition, this scheme needs rescuing more than ever.
An honourable member inte rjecting—
Mr SHORTEN: I don't blame the member for Deakin. Perhaps Senator Reynolds could hang her head in shame.
An honourable member interjecting—

The DEPUTY SPEAKER
( Ms Chesters ): Order! It's not question time.

Mr SHORTEN: We're delivering on our commitment to get the scheme back on track and, importantly, to rebuild trust with participants, families, carers and service providers. We have a range of targeted measures to uplift the capability and systems of the NDIS, to improve innovation, to make access to high-quality supports easier and to provide an overdue boost for our fraud and safety watchdogs. The budget commits a total of $910 million over the next four years to improve the effectiveness and the delivery of the scheme and the safety of NDIS participants.

In 2017 the scheme had about 170,000 participants and 4,000 people working in the agency. Now there are 590,000 people in the scheme, approximately, and still only about 4,000 people working in the agency. It's obvious to all that the agency is understaffed and staff haven't been adequately supported with training and better systems. So we're putting greater support into the staff, because, if the initial planning decision is right, then peak participant experience in the scheme is a much more consistent and predictable matter.

We're also providing $56.4 million to strengthen decision-making and guidance around supported independent living. We're introducing a home and living panel of highly trained staff to improve fairness and consistency. We have also allocated $7.3 million to take us closer to the goal of ensuring no people under 65 are living in residential aged care by 2025. We're also helping to work through reforming the planning. We want to move away, as a default position, from annual plans to longer plans. We want to develop a lifetime approach to planning. Longer plans will take the anxiety and uncertainty out of the issue. Then we move to quality supports and outcomes, but I will hand over to the member for Deakin.

Mr SUKKAR (Deakin) (17:54): I'll start with the NDIS, given that the minister is here and included that in his remarks. The minister talked in his remarks about rebuilding trust in the scheme. One thing that I think we can all say and that we can all give credit to the minister for is that he was ruthlessly efficient in opposition, in a very unprincipled way, in making promises to the sector before the election and, sadly, falling very, very far short after the election. There's no doubt that he raised expectations before the election: that no plan would go backwards, that there were no sustainability issues with the scheme and that brilliant times would be ahead if he were to be minister.
Now he claims that the NDIS is 'growing in its cost base too quickly'. He never mentioned that before the election. Indeed, before the election, he said:
You can't move around the corridors of Parliament in Canberra without tripping over a Coalition Minister whispering the Scheme is unsustainable … I'm here to tell you today that is a lie.

So it's come as a big shock to the sector now to hear from the minister that talking about the sustainability of the NDIS was a big lie before the election but is now the mantra of the government. One questions whether that was imposed on him by the Treasurer or the Prime Minister. One could readily imagine the Prime Minister taking great delight in imposing that on the minister, given he made such promises before the election. I want the minister today to come clean. Does he still believe that the scheme is fully sustainable, or does he agree with the Prime Minister and the Treasurer, who have said that the scheme has sustainability issues?

Indeed, I want the minister to answer how on earth the government came to its arbitrary increase of eight per cent per annum in costs in the scheme, as opposed to the expected increase of 14 per cent. What on earth do those tens of billions of dollars that have now been banked as savings into the forward estimates represent? Who of the 600,000 or so participants in the scheme need to be nervous about where those reductions are coming from? There's been no explanation to date about where those savings will eventuate and who, in the end, will suffer.

We've seen comments from the minister and indeed many in the government in recent times questioning those families with children with an autism diagnosis. There's huge anxiety now, amongst tens of thousands of those families, that they are likely to be the place where the government seeks to get their six per cent saving per annum from. Without any explanation from the government, that is anxiety that is certainly being felt. I think it would be worthy for the minister to get up today and make it very clear to all of those families—tens of thousands, if not hundreds of thousands—that they will not see their plans go backwards, that they will not see their children denied access to the scheme and indeed that future potential participants in the scheme with an autism diagnosis won't be denied access to the scheme.

Right now, we've got a minister who said there were no sustainability issues before the election, but sustainability issues have been the catchcry of the government in relation to the NDIS for months and months now. We then see tens of billions of dollars of banked savings in the budget over the forward estimates, without any explanation as to where those savings will be made. So I invite the minister to make very clear that the existing participants in the scheme won't be paying for those savings that they were promised would never eventuate.

I also invite the minister to clarify why on earth the NDIA were not consulted in relation to the eight per cent growth target. How on earth would you not consult with the agency responsible for the scheme when making such a huge change? The new CEO admitted:
However, we were not consulted on the eight per cent growth target in advance of what was being proposed for discussion at National Cabinet.
Can the minister confirm that he's had those discussions now and that the NDIA is aware of how those savings will be achieved?

Ms COKER (Corangamite) (17:59): Many Australians have described the National Disability Insurance Scheme, when it works, as life changing. When it was first introduced under a Labor government, there was much hope. Ten years later, it's a Labor government, led by the Minister for the NDIS and Minister for Government Services, who is once again listening and acting on the concerns of people with a disability, their families and carers.

As a result of this year's budget, we see federal government's most significant investment ever in the National Disability Insurance Agency, of $721 million, to lift the capability of the agency. Part of this is an investment of more than $73 million to better support participants to manage their plan. A key reform is longer-term planning because we know that short-term plans often create severe ongoing anxiety and frustration. Importantly, the minister is now listening to the disability community, who, under the government's reforms, will not have to re-prove their disability every 12 months.

As the chair of the Parliamentary Joint Standing Committee on the National Disability Insurance Scheme, I've heard such stories often. These heart-wrenching stories are not easy to hear, so I'm pleased we finally have a government that is listening. It's listening to participants, carers and families, and responding to the recommendations from the joint standing committee's 2023 interim report. This budget's $429 million investment to improve the NDIS workforce capability, resulting in better consistency and equity in decision-making, responds to the recommendations in the interim report because the bottom line is: we are here to serve the disability community to make lives better. This budget investment demonstrates this, with a strong focus on rebuilding trust and the capability of staff, to help participants, once again, with compassion and expertise.

Mr SUKKAR (Deakin) (18:01): I will move on to the cashless debit card, in the Social Services portfolio, which, in the litany of failures that we've seen in 12 months from this government, is probably the most spectacular and devastating decision that this government has taken. And, sadly, it's devastating for those people who can afford it the least. The cashless debit card was a program that was requested by a number of communities around our country, who were seeking to address rising problems that they were seeing as a result of alcohol, drugs and other forms of antisocial behaviour. Funds from welfare were being used, sadly, to exacerbate problems that they were seeing in those communities.

The cashless debit card program was very successful in a number of those communities. We warned the government, when it first brought forward its legislation to abolish the cashless debit card, that that decision would have devastating consequences. I remember having very willing discussions over the dispatch box with the minister at the time, asking: how on earth could pouring more alcohol and drugs into vulnerable communities be seen to help those communities? We warned them. We warned the government, and now what do we see? We have seen reports out of a number of former cashless debit card sites of antisocial behaviour, violence, alcohol and drugs getting worse and worse, and almost to the day being able to pinpoint the spike, particularly in crime statistics, to the date on the cashless debit card was abolished by those opposite.

Those opposite, on one hand, denounced the Northern Territory Labor government for what they presided over, yet are now seeking to take that policy nationally to the cashless debit card sites. And every time members of the government interject, they're not just interjecting at me. They're interjecting at those members of the community who have been coming forward and saying, 'We are seeing crime rising in our communities.' Leaders of those communities and members of those communities are seeing it. I ask: what on earth did Australians get for their $217.7 million, one of the single largest additional investments in the October budget, to abolish the CDC, other than more crime, more family violence and more domestic violence, which is coming through in the statistics. We see, in crime statistics out of Ceduna, South Australia, a very clear spike. It has been reported on. Yet Australians have paid $217.7 million, for that terrible outcome.

I ask the ministers: when have they visited those sites, who did they meet with, and have they apologised and explained to those communities that they now understand that abolishing the cashless debit card, or removing its compulsory nature, has led to crime and antisocial behaviour being felt by those communities? If they haven't visited them and apologised in recent weeks, will the ministers commit to getting out to each and every one of those communities and, firstly, apologising for the catastrophic decision to abolish the CDC, and then committing to re-imposing the compulsory nature of the CDC in those communities? This should not be an issue that is prosecuted in the parliament—all decent people should know. You don't need to be an expert, you don't need to have a PhD, you don't need to have a doctorate—pouring alcohol and drugs onto the streets of these communities does not help! More alcohol and more drugs do not help in these communities. It's an absolute outrage that anybody in the government would think that is a decent thing to do. I invite the minister to commit to getting out to those communities and apologising to the people who are suffering now, and to then commit to putting the CDC back into those communities who want them.

Ms PAYNE (Canberra) (18:06): I'm really pleased to rise today as part of this consideration in detail on one of the most important issues facing Australia—that is, housing. Here in the ACT, in my electorate of Canberra, people are experiencing the pressures of housing affordability to a huge extent, as much if not more than anyone around this country. In the 2021 census we learned that 38 per cent of households in the electorate of Canberra were renters compared to the national average of 30.6 per cent. We also know that around nine per cent of Canberra households—
Honourable members interjecting—
Ms PAYNE: That's the state in which my electorate is. I'm part of the ACT. I'm just going to get on with my speech. It would be nice to be heard in silence.

The DEPUTY SPEAKER
( Mr Stevens ): Order! The member will be heard in silence.

Ms PAYNE: We know that around nine per cent of Canberra households have rent or mortgage repayments greater than 30 per cent of their household incomes, meaning nine per cent of Canberrans are currently living in either rental or mortgage stress. While Canberra is a relatively well-off community, with average incomes higher than the national average and relatively low unemployment, it means that it is a very difficult place to live on a low income, and that our rents and housing costs are very high in this city. Approximately 1,160 Canberrans on census night were experiencing homelessness, making up around 0.8 per cent of our city's population.

So these issues are really acute. I found this recently as I have run a deliberative process, the Canberra Forum, over the last six months, which involves 40 randomly selected Canberrans who come together to choose a topic and make recommendations to me. The topic that they chose after much thoughtful consideration was housing. They have spent time hearing from experts and working on that. I was incredibly pleased and thankful to have the Minister for Housing and Homelessness come and address that group. I know the group found that discussion with her to be very important. Something that was really important to this group of Canberrans is that housing be seen as a human right, so I'm very pleased this is exactly how our government and our minister and our Prime Minister see housing. This is an incredibly important issue right now for Australians. It's central to the dignity and wellbeing of each and every Australian.

Right now, in the Senate, we are trying to get through our $10 billion Housing Australia Future Fund to deliver 30,000 new social and affordable homes in its first five years, and investments of $500 million per year into social and affordable homes. This is also prioritising housing for women and children escaping domestic violence and for veterans facing homelessness. My question is: how could anybody in this place who is listening to their constituents vote against new homes being built, particularly for those priority groups? If they are truly listening to anyone in their electorates who is experiencing these issues, I don't understand how they can vote this way. I'm talking about those in the Liberal-National coalition and in the Greens who are failing to support this incredibly important future fund that we are establishing to build homes because we believe housing is a human right and centrally important.

This is just one of the things we are doing to invest in housing at the moment. To talk again about the ACT, part of which I represent in this place, in the 2022-23 budget our government provided assistance to three Reconnect services in the ACT, namely Gugan Gulwan Youth Aboriginal Corporation, CatholicCare Canberra & Goulburn, and Queanbeyan Multilingual Centre. The Reconnect program is a community based early intervention program for young people aged between 12 and 21, and these three particular organisations have assisted 140 young people experiencing or at risk of homelessness to get secure housing. We are a government that understands that safe and affordable housing is central to the security and dignity of all Australians.

The housing accord we announced in last year's budget includes federal funding to deliver 10,000 affordable homes over five years. The Regional First Home Buyer Guarantee is already helping thousands of Australians into home ownership after the Albanese government brought forward its launch by three months. Again, my question is: how could anyone not get behind these measures to build more homes for Australians?

Mr SUKKAR (Deakin) (18:11): I'll follow up on housing after that contribution. I would say—I was listening intently—perhaps the member should get on the phone to the ACT Labor government, who might have some control over the issues she described in the ACT. She should ask them to stop constraining housing supply, as they've been doing for many years. Fess up to your constituents—that's the first thing I'd say.

In relation to housing, I think there are probably few areas in the government which have seen an agenda as much in tatters as the very thin housing agenda. I think it's great the minister is here and she should answer these questions. I would ask the minister: does she recommit to the one million homes aspiration? It was a promise in the October budget. It's now been downgraded, sadly, to an aspiration, which I think will give anyone watching this a clue as to the likelihood of the minister recommitting to it. With some fanfare, we heard in the October budget that the government was committing to the private sector effectively delivering one million homes over five years. They forgot to mention that, actually, one million homes over five years have been delivered for a very long time and that's business as usual. But we now see that promise in absolute tatters. There's no way any serious economist thinks the government will reach that aspiration now.

I would also ask the minister to outline in some detail when on earth the Help to Buy Scheme will start. The Help to Buy Scheme was supposed to start on 1 January. We came to the parliament last year expecting that it would be in front of us because it was supposed to commence on 1 January. Now it's a fair bit after 1 January and we don't even have draft legislation or a bill in front of us. We've had no announcement from the government. As a former housing minister I know it does take a lot of work to deliver those programs, but you do have to deliver them in the time promised. It was supposed to start on 1 January. The Prime Minister spoke about cheaper mortgages. I'm not sure there are many Australians who have one of those very precious cheaper mortgages, so I want the minister to answer: when will we see the Help to Buy Scheme start? Admittedly, it was a commitment made by her predecessor in a shadow portfolio role, but when will it start? Get moving, guys. Get moving and get some work done.

The minister has been out there—in a very flattering way, I think—spruiking the Home Guarantee Scheme, which was my creation that I delivered as housing minister, and I agree with the housing minister. The Home Guarantee Scheme is a remarkable scheme not only for first-home buyers but for single parents. That was a great expansion to the scheme, which I was very proud to put in place. And of course we see through not only the regional scheme but also the general scheme that in regional areas the Home Guarantee Scheme is helping. But I ask the minister: what on earth is the government doing other than delivering Coalition landmark policies like the Home Guarantee Scheme? What assistance are they providing to first-home buyers?

I also note that in the last TLA bill we saw the government committed to adopting the former coalition government's First Home Super Saver Scheme, another policy I was very proud to deliver as minister. It seems that they are now committing to it after promising that they would abolish it. Can the minister confirm that they do now see the virtue in another landmark scheme, the First Home Super Saver Scheme?

Finally, can the minister today table the investment mandate for their so-called Housing Australia Future Fund? Can the minister outline how the Housing Australia Future Fund will be administered? Will it be required to repay the $400 million or so in interest that it will cost in borrowings to the Commonwealth? What is the cost to the Commonwealth of the Future Fund administering the scheme? Will the Housing Australia Future Fund, which is not due to commence until the middle of 2024, deliver enough homes for the 1.5 million migrants that the government will be bringing in over the same period? If so, how on earth will 1.5 million migrants live in so-called 30,000 homes, which we are very dubious will ever be delivered?

Ms COLLINS (Franklin—Minister for Housing, Minister for Homelessness and Minister for Small Business) (18:17): I'm really proud of our government's ambitious housing agenda. We are doing more than any federal government has done in the past in terms of housing and housing affordability. Indeed, there was very little action from those opposite, but I'm glad to see that the shadow minister is talking about Help to Buy, which is our shared equity scheme. Given the shadow minister is so interested in it, I hope that means he will support it when it comes into this place, because this is a good scheme. We are talking about a shared equity scheme with 30 per cent or 40 per cent—depending on whether it's an existing or new home—government equity in a person's home. It is to make it easier for people to get into their homes. We remain committed to our Help to Buy shared equity scheme and we look forward to implementing it, hopefully with the opposition's support given they're so interested in it.

We have, of course, helped more than 50,000 Australians into their first home through the Home Guarantee Scheme in the first 12 months of our government. We are making changes to that to modernise the scheme and to improve the scheme. We added to the scheme with the Regional First Home Buyer Guarantee, which is going really well right across regional Australia. You saw in this budget more in terms of our housing agenda. You saw changes to build-to-rent to incentivise more build-to-rent in Australia. We need to get this up and running. The Property Council is talking about an additional 150,000 to 250,000 dwellings because of the changes that we made in the last budget, and we have already seen more build to rent being proposed around the country since that announcement on budget.

We also saw in the budget the biggest increase in Commonwealth rental assistance in more than 30 years. We're talking about a 15 per cent increase directly into the pockets of renters who are eligible for the Commonwealth Rent Assistance scheme. We know, of course, that renters are doing it tough. Thirty per cent of Australians are now renters, which is why we're doing this.
The shadow minister was also talking about the Housing Australia Future Fund. This is a fund which they've claimed that they're opposing.
Mr Sukkar interjecting—

Ms COLLINS: I say to the shadow minister: will this make you change your mind? We are committed to the Housing Australia Future Fund. We're talking about 30,000 additional social and affordable homes in the first five years of the fund. That is a very significant investment and a very significant turnaround in terms of investment in social and affordable homes from a federal government. What we want to do is work with the states and territories, with local government and indeed with community housing providers to build capacity and leverage other investments such as institutional investment from superannuation funds and overseas pension funds. We know that there is a lot of interest in investing in this area. We want to be able to do this so that more Australians have a safe, affordable place to call home. We are working right across the board, whether it be for direct homeownership or for more social and affordable housing, right across the housing agenda. We have put renters' rights on the National Cabinet agenda, where we are talking about making sure that all renters across Australia know what their rights are. We want to lift it to make sure that no renter loses any existing rights but has some consistency so that people that are renting in Australia understand clearly what their rights are and they can have a bit more power in their hands.

We of course had the National Housing Accord in our October budget last year, our first budget. We have always talked about an aspirational target of a million homes. We are working with the sector and the construction sector, which together with states and territories and institutional investors have signed up to the National Housing Accord. We are working with states and territories about what reforms are going to be required to meet this number because we are serious about working with them on reform to get more homes on the ground more quickly and, importantly, to make sure that they are the right homes. We need to make sure that people can afford to live close to where they work or where they go to school. That is the whole point of the National Housing Accord. It is about making sure that we work with other tiers of government and with the sector so that we get the right homes in the right places. We want to plan this better.

We, of course, have also had a boost to homelessness, unfortunately. There are far too many Australians living with homelessness at the moment, so we boosted funding by $67.5 million in addition to what was already in the National Housing and Homelessness Agreement, with a one-year extension now totalling $1.7 billion going to the states and territories to support people who need that support the most. We will continue to do that every single day.

Mr FLETCHER (Bradfield—Manager of Opposition Business) (18:22): The opposition has needed to consistently remind this government that we are in a cost-of-living crisis, and that is why it is so important that government services are delivered efficiently and also important that government ministers with responsibility for the delivery of services make themselves available to participate in parliamentary mechanisms of accountability and transparency. But when it comes to the member for Maribyrnong, his contempt for parliamentary accountability and scrutiny knows no bounds. He has repeatedly failed to meet the deadlines for questions asked of him in estimates in relation to his dismal performance in government services. He has consistently failed to answer questions in writing within the mandated time, and now tonight he has shown his contempt for this additional mechanism of parliamentary accountability and scrutiny because he can't even be bothered to turn up to answer questions in the consideration in detail process. It is absolutely disgraceful that the minister couldn't be bothered to be here, and what is equally disgraceful is the dismal performance of Services Australia under his watch, with Australians waiting longer and longer on the phone to actually speak with somebody at Centrelink or at Services Australia.

New data obtained by the opposition has confirmed that in this financial year to 31 March 2023 over three million Australians chose to terminate their call with Centrelink, instead of waiting to actually speak to a customer service officer. What is worse is that call waiting times have risen dramatically under this Labor government. It's taking on average over 31 minutes for Australians to be connected with Centrelink when they are calling about the Child Care Subsidy. If they are calling the employment services line there is an average wait time of 29 minutes, valuable time that could otherwise be spent looking for a job. But Labor is making it harder for jobseekers to do what they want to do and what they should be doing. You would think that a Labor government would prioritise unclogging these lines during a cost-of-living crisis when Australians are in need of receiving government payments and services. Before the election, the Minister for Government Services promised to improve the frontline delivery of services. He made that promise, and people who are naive, people who haven't had the unfortunate experience of dealing with the member for Maribyrnong over many years, might have been fooled into taking that promise at face value. That would've been a grave mistake. It would've shown a real lack of experience in the conduct and the behaviour of the member for Maribyrnong over his entire undistinguished period of public life.

He promised to improve the frontline delivery of services, but that commitment clearly has not extended to telephony, so I ask: what are the minister's plans to stop the stratospheric and continuing increase in Centrelink call waiting times under this government? What is the minister going to do about that? What's he going to do about the fall in staffing levels at Centrelink—dramatically falling from 28,560 this financial year to 26,692 in the next financial year?

What is this Minister for Government Services going to do about improving digital service delivery? Under the previous government, this was a major focus. The highly successful myGov app is a very good example of that, planned, developed and funded by the coalition. But what we have discovered through Senate estimates is that Labor have cut almost $250 million from Services Australia for service transformation. The funding announced in the budget, as the minister himself has described it, is simply to 'sustain' this vital platform. This is in stark contrast to the former coalition government's investment in myGov. We locked in funding for sustainment and enhancement, and that's essential.

We didn't just stop at myGov. Look at the $1.6 billion dollars we delivered for the Welfare Payment Infrastructure Transformation Program, an overhaul of Centrelink's IT systems. With no dedicating funding under this government to improve how the government delivers services digitally, Australians can expect a far more clunky, outdated and ultimately unsafe user experience. Ironically, the direction that the minister is pursuing is entirely the opposite of the direction he was encouraged to pursue through the myGov user audit. Why has the minister so fundamentally dropped the ball on improving services, particularly those digital services which we now know Australians overwhelmingly prefer to use? I put that question. If the minister were here, instead of being too gutless to turn up, he could answer the questions.

Mr HILL (Bruce) (18:27): I'm incredibly pleased to see the measures in this budget on women's safety. I think it's important that men also take an interest and speak up on women's safety, because, frankly, it is everyone's business. We've seen a major cultural change in our country over recent decades, from the 1970s and 1980s. Domestic, sexual and family violence is no longer considered a private matter. It's a community responsibility, and rightly so. It's not a 'women's' problem to be solved—it doesn't affect only women, but it does affect women overwhelmingly—it's the community's problem to be solved. But the community can only do that with sustained government support. I consider that in the October budget and now, in this budget, no-one could possibly doubt the government's commitment to ending violence against women and children and ensuring women's safety. There has been $2.29 billion—that's billion with a b—invested in just two budgets.

Anyone who thinks that women's safety or the women's portfolio is marginal or peripheral in this government does not understand this government. They fail to understand the government's agenda and its purpose. Unlike the former government, gender equality is at the core of everything that this government does. Frankly, this should always be a bipartisan thing, and it's welcome that the Leader of the Opposition said in his budget reply speech—in amongst the dog whistling—that he supports our measures in this budget on women's safety.

But they just can't help themselves with their negativity, can they? I've got a little press release here. It was issued on 4 June—my birthday, actually; I called my birthday 'my next 40th'; it was a special birthday—by the Hon. Sussan Ley, the Deputy Leader of the Opposition, and senator someone, whom I've never heard of. They were having a crack at the government's commitment of $169 million for 500 new frontline service and community workers over four years. That's 500 workers over four years. Of course, they need to be delivered through the states and territories, and negotiations for that commenced in December. So we announced this—what—six, seven months ago but, apparently, the fact that 500 workers haven't been delivered over seven months while we were doing it through the states and territories showed we have failed, that our commitment was in tatters, that it was a black mark and it prompted the opposition to sound the alarm on the government's performance on women's safety. Questioning the first national action plan under the national plan won't be delivered until August is inexcusable. A little prone to hyperbole but perhaps the deputy leader of the opposition's numerologist told her to use those words—you never know. But to be clear, the 500 workers will be delivered via the states and territories in a proper process.

I can understand why the opposition are confused, because when it comes to the arrangements of the Morrison government, ignoring proper process was something they excelled in. It was one of their very few special talents. Samantha Maiden reported that Chanel Contos met with a political staffer from the Morrison government for coffee in March 2022, who told her she was getting $8 million—that's a pretty good deal for coffee, isn't it—despite never having putting a submission in for funding. No submission for funding, one coffee, $8 million—that is proper process for the Liberal and Nationals. But it is not surprising that when the Morrison government had a problem with women they scrambled for a solution, made deals over coffee so they could get an announcement. But they didn't actually deliver.

The 500 new staff, as this budget shows, is on top of extending the national partnership. Of course, the national partnership—the rhetorical commitment to women's safety of those opposite—was another one of those booby-trapped measures that we inherited, because there was no funding from 30 June. The national partnership was expiring, so all those frontline services that support victim-survivors were facing a funding cut. But that is consistent with their record on women's safety. It was those opposite who thought milkshake ads were a good use of taxpayers' money to teach younger Australians about consent. It was those opposite who said their budget was good for women because women can take advantage of driving on new infrastructure and roads—terrific! That is gender equality. I mean, that is a fall from the glory days when Tony Abbott appointed himself as minister for women because he forgot to appoint one. There was only one woman out of the 18 in the cabinet—poor lonely Julie Bishop.

Scott Morrison famously told the parliament that the women protesting outside for their rights to be free of sexual harassment and violence were 'lucky not to be shot' in our democracy. I am proud to serve in a caucus and a government with 53 per cent women that reflects the diversity of the Australian population. We have had an entire bloke fest over there for this whole debate. Shame on them.

Mr CONAGHAN (Cowper) (18:32): Family and domestic violence in this country continue to be a scourge on our whole society. This government's national prevention plan is a commendable continuation and adaptation of the coalition's plan before it, which was built on successive plans of successive governments. But as each year passes, the statistics keep rolling in and they get worse and worse and worse. That is not me saying it; that is the data speaking. I believe that we have to face the reality that nothing intrinsically revolutionary has happened in the area of prevention. I'm not being critical of any government. I am saying, as a police officer of 30 years ago, working in my home town of Kempsey, nothing has changed, because there has been no revolutionary change in the way we address this. What has increased are the cases being prosecuted in courts. That might be because we have had a societal shift in reporting and an acceptance that this is not something that is behind closed doors. But in the keyword—prevention—there has been no paradigm shift.

As the shadow assistant minister for the prevention of family violence, last month I was in the Northern Territory and South Australia to continue consultations I've been undertaking in the domestic and family violence space. I met with representatives of law enforcement, Indigenous men's services, Relationships Australia, and drug and alcohol services in Darwin, Alice Springs and Adelaide. After a year of speaking with individuals, community groups and professional organisations, it is clear that a one-size-fits-all approach is not appropriate across the country. It is imperative that any proposed measures take into account the affected community's unique requirements, and, as a government, I believe we need to provide a toolbox approach to family violence. It's imperative that any proposed measures take into account the affected communities' unique requirements. I believe that as a government we need to provide that toolbox approach to family violence. What I mean by that is: the essential kit that can be broken down for those communities to use, and for those tools to be appropriately weighted towards prevention.

It's clear that more funding needs to be directed towards prevention—and yes, we need that funding for response and recovery. It's also increasingly clear that the physical resourcing on the ground, at the coalface across the country, is critically inadequate. A focused approach needs to be taken quickly to better equip our existing providers and allow them to expand those services to address it successfully in the community. With this in mind, I was pleased to see the government had dedicated $169.4 million over four years for an additional 500 frontline community workers, with 200 earmarked for this year. I'd hoped to see transparent processes for identifying the areas most in need of additional supports—unfortunately, at this stage, none of those bodies promised for the coalface have actually been delivered, and I am uncertain how the allocation process will take place. My first question to the minister is: why have none of these promised workers been delivered and what is the process in determining where these workers are to be assigned?

Additionally, I note that the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander national plan will now take 18 months to two years to put in place. Given the gravity the domestic violence problem in the First Nations community—which is a fact we all agree on—I cannot understand why it should take so long. Comparatively, I was recently a member of the Joint Select Committee on the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Voice Referendum—a group that spent just five days on an inquiry around a referendum on Constitutional change, yet we need another two years for a separate plan for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people before we can put actions into place. My second question to the minister is: why is this process so conflated, given the immediate and urgent need?

Mrs ELLIOT (Richmond—Assistant Minister for Social Services and Assistant Minister for the Prevention of Family Violence) (18:37): I'm very pleased to be speaking tonight on our budget measures, their range and extent, and the assistance they provide. This is a budget that strengthens our safety net and improves the lives of so many vulnerable Australians, including people with a disability, First Nations peoples, and women and children escaping domestic violence.

We know that many Australians are doing it tough at the moment, and households are really feeling the pinch with cost-of-living pressures. That's why, in our budget —our responsible budget—we are still delivering assistance to those people that require it the most. The budget delivers a $14.6 billion cost-of-living package, and in the social services portfolio alone we are providing $10 billion to strengthen our safety net—building on our investment in women's safety, addressing entrenched community disadvantage, supporting people with disability, and improving the wellbeing of Australians. Our budget delivers to Australians through a whole range of measures that we have spoken about—energy price relief, cheaper medicines, improvements to bulk-billing, more affordable child care, extended paid parental leave, and our measures on top of that.

I want to touch on our increases to JobSeeker. We're providing $4.9 billion to increase the rates of JobSeeker for more than one million Australians. This will provide a further $40 a fortnight for those receiving youth allowance, parenting payments, Austudy, Abstudy, the youth disability support pension, and special benefits. Very importantly, we are expending eligibility for the existing higher rate of JobSeeker to support single recipients aged 55 and over who have been on income support for nine or more continuous months. We're doing this because we know that many older Australians face additional barriers when it comes to looking for work, particularly age discrimination. This reform will expand access to around 52,000 eligible Australians, who will receive an increase of $92.10 per fortnight.

Also important, we are providing the largest increase to Commonwealth rent assistance in more than 30 years. This is a vitally important move and will have a huge impact upon those who are receiving Commonwealth rent assistance. It's part of one of the many housing measures that we've brought out as we are looking to address the housing and homelessness crisis. And of course our Housing Australia Future Fund is a vitally important component of that. I call again upon those across the aisle in the opposition, and also those in the Greens, to really support our initiatives to make sure we can provide affordable housing.

Very importantly, on the single parenting payment, we are investing $1.9 billion to strengthen the safety net for single parents. We know that it's vitally important to do that. We know how difficult it can be for single parents to balance their caring responsibilities and full-time work, and we know that that doesn't end when a child turns eight. So we're expanding eligibility—increasing the age cut-off for the parent's youngest child from eight to 14.

Now I would like to speak on the very important issue of women's safety. I know this is an issue that everyone in this parliament is absolutely committed to. We are making women's safety a national priority. We know how important it is to deliver that change. Governments across Australia have come together with the goal to end violence against women and children in one generation. I know every member of this House shares in that goal.

To help us get there, this budget will provide an additional $589 million to further support women's safety, and that includes, of course, the implementation of our National Plan to End Violence against Women and Children—so vitally important. This investment will fund critical measures around prevention, early intervention, holding perpetrators to account and, particularly, ensuring that children are also seen as victim-survivors in their own right. We know how important is to address all of these issues. We also have a strong focus on supporting the safety of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander women; taking action on sexual violence; supporting the economic security of victim-survivors; and supporting women on temporary visas and victim-survivors of trafficking. This package also includes $159 million of additional funding for states and territories to support frontline service delivery, under the family, domestic and sexual violence national partnership, and we've committed over $262 million towards measures for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander women and children, through our dedicated action plan. Our investment in this year's budget is of course on top of our record investment of $1.7 billion in women's safety, which we saw in the October budget, bringing our total investment to over $2 billion.

As I say, we have a national focus on leadership when it comes to making sure that we can end that violence against women and children in one generation. I know that every member of this House shares in that goal, in terms of achieving it. It's vitally important for the future.

Ms CHANEY (Curtin) (18:42): I appreciate this opportunity to ask questions of the government in relation to the social security budget. My first questions are to the Minister for Social Services. The government created an economic inclusion advisory committee to provide advice in the lead-up to budgets on policies to address disadvantage and boost economic participation. I have two questions about this committee. Firstly, when will the government introduce legislation to establish this committee as a permanent committee, and who will be appointed to it? Secondly, will the government implement or respond to recommendations of the committee, and, if so, in what time frame? The committee found the current rates of JobSeeker and related payments were seriously inadequate. It recommended restoring the relativities of the mid-1990s, when employment benefits were about 90 per cent of the age pension. ACOSS has issued an open letter calling for this $19 a day increase. This has been signed by a huge range of MPs, community leaders, economists, prominent leaders and academics. The BCA and CEDA backed this change too. ANU analysis shows that we could increase government spending by about one per cent and lift a million people out of poverty. I acknowledge that we need to address the structural deficit in the budget. Inflation affects everyone. But, in a budget of $680 billion, surely we can find $6 billion so that all Australians can be fed and housed and live with dignity.

My next question is to the Minister for the National Disability Insurance Scheme. The NDIS will cover 600,000 people this month; it is forecast to increase to more than a million people by 2032 and cost close to $100 billion annually. The NDIS is a fundamentally important part of our welfare system and will need to be sustainable on an ongoing basis. So I ask the minister: what's being done to address the sustainability challenges for the NDIS over the coming decades?

My final questions are addressed to the Minister for Housing and Minister for Homelessness. The Housing Australia Future Fund is a small piece of the puzzle when it comes to the challenges we face on housing. It's understandable that successive governments have shied away from addressing underlying affordability issues, because the decline in house prices is politically unpalatable for those who are already in the housing market as owners or investors. We need to take a long-term view, and my question for the minister is whether she'll listen to the suggestion put by the crossbench and support a citizens' assembly on housing so we have new reform ideas on the table for the next budget and the government has permission to drive some longer term reform so people can reasonably aspire to put a roof over their heads and eventually own their own homes.
I urge the relevant ministers to address these questions to ensure that we are, in fact, giving people a fair go and that we'll be able to continue to do this in the future.
Proposed expenditure agreed to.
Consideration in Detail
